ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Combining Interactive Evolution with Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Joel, Please see below. ... I understand that the map stops being filled up when the first org hits the goal. I never said it was a fault of NS that it

Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Combining Interactive Evolution with Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=cHIRJGRXp39hCsRbIWggi9jjLgBLVQeHdIITgWPo8w4k7F58unXz
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_3AD08F39-2A4C-41FC-95E3-478F5BA15DD3
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hi Joel,

Please see below. 

> One thing that might be useful for the disc=
ussion is to point out that figures such as fig 7 in the novelty search cor=
pus are generated based on points visited up until either *the problem is s=
olved* or all evaluations are exhausted, and as such in this case do not re=
veal the behavior of novelty search if run longer (e.g. if it ran as long a=
s the raw fitness-based search, which usually exhausts all allotted evaluat=
ions). In other words, for novelty search it just reveals which behaviors a=
re typically discovered *before* a solution is evolved. If novelty search w=
as run longer, it would likely fill in those areas (I may generate such a r=
un and visualization to verify that is the case, but I believe I looked at =
that before and it was the case).
> 
> In any case, it may not be surprisin=
g that NS fails to fill in all of the behavior space in a perfectly orderly=
 way before it evolves a solution. This may indicate not a fault in NS, but=
 a subtle point regarding the temporal dynamics of exploring a space of beh=
aviors. Note that NS is exploring this space of behaviors indirectly throug=
h sampling maze-navigating policies; and complexification in NEAT generally=
 constrains that search in an order from simple policies to more complex po=
licies. 
> 

I understand that the map stops being filled up when the first=
 org hits the goal. I never said it was a fault of NS that it doesn=92t fil=
l the top right corner. On the contrary, I think it is a fascinating and am=
azing beneficial thing that it has this non-linear skill jump where suddenl=
y it gains a skill that works so well that it skips to the solution when on=
ly half way down the path to the goal. I=92m just trying to (a) confirm tha=
t is what happens, and (b) understand what is going on at that moment, and =
most importantly, (c) figure out why it works in NS and Fitness (and, of co=
urse, why it doesn=92t happen in the other treatments). 

> Importantly, to=
 reach an arbitrary interior point of the maze far from the start likely re=
quires a more complex (and perhaps equally arbitrary) policy than do the si=
mpler wall-following variants that hug the walls and reach the end of the m=
aze.

To some extent that=92s true. But the other treatments show that mayb=
e such solutions aren=92t more complex, since in those treatments they are =
found first. I can see arguments both ways: if you have a general solution,=
 it=92s complex to get it to stop anywhere in particular. But it=92s also q=
uite complex to find a general solution instead of the collection of hacks =
that show up in NA-IEC, right?

> In other words, it may be that once NS di=
scovers a wall-follower that escapes the walls near the maze-start, that is=
 a key innovation which leads quickly to a solution; in this way, the searc=
h is terminated before NS is pushed to explore more complex refinements to =
the wall-following policy that end in more arbitrary points of the maze int=
erior away from walls.

That=92s the magic I=92m trying to highlight! It=92=
s pretty incredible that this huge jump in exploratory skills occurs. Why d=
o you think it occurs in NS and Fit, but not the others (e.g. waypoint)? 

=
> So perhaps when Ken and I talk about NS filling in the space of behaviors=
, it is important to keep in mind that this filling may not happen in a lin=
ear way, but relates more to a non-linear filling in based on how policies =
are interconnected with other novel policies reachable through mutation.
> =

> Another important point is that there is a difference between how novelt=
y search *the algorithm* is exploring the behavior space, and the general a=
bility of a particular individual evolved by novelty search *to explore*. I=
 felt like your email might have conflated these two concepts, although I c=
ould be mistaken. To make the distinction clear though, each point in that =
figure represents only where a particular maze navigating robot ends within=
 the maze, but does not necessarily imply anything about that individual's =
generality over other mazes. Indeed, one hypothesis is that in some domains=
 NS may evolve more general skills than objective-based search (and some of=
 Ken and I's work on evolvability supports that, with some nuance, as we've=
 discussed in a related thread), and while that idea does bear further exam=
ination, I am not sure that the class of figure you are referencing necessa=
rily provides evidence for or against that hypothesis.

I don=92t think I=
=92m conflating the concepts (and I understand what the data represent). 

=
Why don=92t you think the absence of points in the 2nd half of the =93path =
to the goal=94 indicates general exploratory skills, such as wall following=
? Isn=92t that precisely the explanation you provide for why the points don=
=92t exist? Those robots are wall following in parts of the maps (and thus =
situations) they have not encountered before, and seem to do just fine, so =
shouldn=92t those skills lead to general exploratory skills in other maps?
=

To reiterate: I am focusing on what I think is an amazing property that se=
ems to be surfacing in NS and am just trying to understand it better. I=92m=
 also surprised that it shows up in Fitness, but not in Waypoint: I can=92t=
 come up with a good explanation of that. But I=92m definitely not claiming=
 that this data shows a limitation of NS. Instead, it seems like something =
important is being generated by NS and I=92d like to understand it more. As=
 I mentioned in the original post, it is this amazing jump in skills that c=
aused Roby and I to go looking for more evidence that there is indeed a ski=
ll jump. We found evidence for it, but what I didn=92t appreciate until our=
 work and the NA-IEC paper is that for some reason fitness search also exhi=
bits this skill jump. That is surprising, but I can come up with reasons wh=
y it might be true. But then when I saw that it isn=92t the case that all s=
earch algorithms produce this jump (e.g. Waypoint, NA-IEC, etc.)=85that=92s=
 when I really started to get puzzled=85and that is where I currently remai=
n!

:0)

Best,
Jeff

> 
> Best,
> Joel
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_3AD08F39-2A4C-41FC-95E3-478F5BA15DD3

div><div><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255,=

=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=
=3D"ygrp-text"><div>One thing that might be useful for the discussion is to=
 point out that figures such as fig 7 in the novelty search corpus are gene=
rated based on points visited up until either *the problem is solved* or al=
l evaluations are exhausted, and as such in this case do not reveal the beh=
avior of novelty search if run longer (e.g. if it ran as long as the raw fi=
tness-based search, which usually exhausts all allotted evaluations). In ot=
her words, for novelty search it just reveals which behaviors are typically=
 discovered *before* a solution is evolved. If novelty search was run longe=
r, it would likely fill in those areas (I may generate such a run and visua=
lization to verify that is the case, but I believe I looked at that before =
and it was the case).</div><div><br></div><div>In any case, it may not be s=
urprising that NS fails to fill in all of the behavior space in a perfectly=
 orderly way before it evolves a solution. This may indicate not a fault in=
 NS, but a subtle point regarding the temporal dynamics of exploring a spac=
e of behaviors. Note that NS is exploring this space of behaviors indirectl=
y through sampling maze-navigating policies; and complexification in NEAT g=
enerally constrains that search in an order from simple policies to more co=
mplex policies. </div><div><br></div></div></div></div></div></blockqu=
ote><div><br></div><div>I understand that the map stops being filled up whe=
n the first org hits the goal. I never said it was a <b>fault</b> of NS tha=
t it doesn=92t fill the top right corner. On the contrary, I think it is a =
fascinating and amazing beneficial thing that it has this non-linear skill =
jump where suddenly it gains a skill that works so well that it skips to th=
e solution when only half way down the path to the goal. I=92m just trying =
to (a) confirm that is what happens, and (b) understand what is going on at=
 that moment, and most importantly, (c) figure out why it works in NS and F=
itness (and, of course, why it doesn=92t happen in the other treatments).&n=
bsp;</div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb=
(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" s=
tyle=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div=
 id=3D"ygrp-text">Importantly, to reach an arbitrary interior point of the =
maze far from the start likely requires a more complex (and perhaps equally=
 arbitrary) policy than do the simpler wall-following variants that hug the=
 walls and reach the end of the maze.</div></div></div></div></blockquote><=
div><br></div><div>To some extent that=92s true. But the other treatments s=
how that maybe such solutions aren=92t more complex, since in those treatme=
nts they are found first. I can see arguments both ways: if you have a gene=
ral solution, it=92s complex to get it to stop anywhere in particular. But =
it=92s also quite complex to find a general solution instead of the collect=
ion of hacks that show up in NA-IEC, right?</div><br><blockquote type=3D"ci=
te"><div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z=
-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlmsg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=
=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"> In other words, =
it may be that once NS discovers a wall-follower that escapes the walls nea=
r the maze-start, that is a key innovation which leads quickly to a solutio=
n; in this way, the search is terminated before NS is pushed to explore mor=
e complex refinements to the wall-following policy that end in more arbitra=
ry points of the maze interior away from walls. </div></div></div></div></b=
lockquote><div><br></div><div>That=92s the magic I=92m trying to highlight!=
 It=92s pretty incredible that this huge jump in exploratory skills occurs.=
 Why do you think it occurs in NS and Fit, but not the others (e.g. waypoin=
t)? </div><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div style=3D"background-color=
: rgb(255, 255, 255); position: static; z-index: auto;"><div id=3D"ygrp-mlm=
sg" style=3D"position:relative;"><div id=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"=
><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><div>So perhaps when Ken and I talk about NS filling=
 in the space of behaviors, it is important to keep in mind that this filli=
ng may not happen in a linear way, but relates more to a non-linear filling=
 in based on how policies are interconnected with other novel policies reac=
hable through mutation.</div><div><br></div><div>Another important point is=
 that there is a difference between how novelty search *the algorithm* is e=
xploring the behavior space, and the general ability of a particular indivi=
dual evolved by novelty search *to explore*. I felt like your email might h=
ave conflated these two concepts, although I could be mistaken. To make the=
 distinction clear though, each point in that figure represents only where =
a particular maze navigating robot ends within the maze, but does not neces=
sarily imply anything about that individual's generality over other mazes. =
Indeed, one hypothesis is that in some domains NS may evolve more general s=
kills than objective-based search (and some of Ken and I's work on evolvabi=
lity supports that, with some nuance, as we've discussed in a related threa=
d), and while that idea does bear further examination, I am not sure that t=
he class of figure you are referencing necessarily provides evidence for or=
 against that hypothesis.</div></div></div></div></div></blockquote><div><b=
r></div><div>I don=92t think I=92m conflating the concepts (and I understan=
d what the data represent). </div><div><br></div><div>Why don=92t you =
think the absence of points in the 2nd half of the =93path to the goal=94 i=
ndicates general exploratory skills, such as wall following? Isn=92t that p=
recisely the explanation you provide for why the points don=92t exist? Thos=
e robots are wall following in parts of the maps (and thus situations) they=
 have not encountered before, and seem to do just fine, so shouldn=92t thos=
e skills lead to general exploratory skills in other maps?</div><div><br></=
div><div>To reiterate: I am focusing on what I think is an amazing property=
 that seems to be surfacing in NS and am just trying to understand it bette=
r. I=92m also surprised that it shows up in Fitness, but not in Waypoint: I=
 can=92t come up with a good explanation of that. But I=92m definitely not =
claiming that this data shows a limitation of NS. Instead, it seems like so=
mething important is being generated by NS and I=92d like to understand it =
more. As I mentioned in the original post, it is this amazing jump in skill=
s that caused Roby and I to go looking for more evidence that there is inde=
ed a skill jump. We found evidence for it, but what I didn=92t appreciate u=
ntil our work and the NA-IEC paper is that for some reason fitness search a=
lso exhibits this skill jump. That is surprising, but I can come up with re=
asons why it might be true. But then when I saw that it isn=92t the case th=
at all search algorithms produce this jump (e.g. Waypoint, NA-IEC, etc.)=85=
that=92s when I really started to get puzzled=85and that is where I current=
